results.title: Minister of hate
results.creator_credit: Burton Benjamin, CBS News and Kenco Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
Examines the techniques of mass thought control evolved by the brilliant, ruthless Nazi minister, Joseph Goebbels, and shows the dangerous effects which totalitarian control of communications can have on a society. Includes Fritz Lang commenting briefly on his meeting with Goebbels. Narrated by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: From kaiser to fuehrer
results.creator_credit: Burton Benjamin and United States Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
This film relates the history of the ill-fated Weimar Republic, from after the first World War to 1933. Attributes the causes of the fall of the Republic to the depression, inexperience with democracy and the doubts of many of its adherents.

results.title: The Dust bowl
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, Burton Benjamin and CBS News
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
Contrasts past and present conditions of the Dust Bowl area of the Southern Great Plains. Provides newsreel footage of the area during the dust storms period of the early 1930s. Narrated by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Ataturk: father of modern Turkey
results.creator_credit: Burton Benjamin and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
Explains how, at the end of World War I, Mustapha Kemal Ataturk took over government and began to Westernise the country. Discusses the various projects he started.

results.title: From generation to generation
results.brief_description: The behaviour of the reproductive cells (wherein according to one theory the determinants of heredity are thought to be contained), together with the division of the nucleus in ordinary cell division, and the formation of reproductive cells, are illustrated by animated diagrams. Fertilization is explained by both animation and direct photography, and examples of the basic Mendelian principles of segregation and recombination are shown in rabbits, guinea pigs, and cattle. The white angora rabbit and the single-combed fowl are used as examples of the emergence of new types from the crossing of parents exhibiting independent pairs of Mendelian characteristics. The results of selective breeding of horses and dogs are also shown.

results.title: From Doric to Gothic
results.creator_credit: Andre Gillet, Marcel De Hubsch and Brandon Films
results.brief_description: This film reviews the development of architectural forms from the basic column and lintel construction of Greek temples, through the Roman basilica style and Romanesque churches to the groining and buttressing of Gothic cathedrals. The importance of development of arch and the later lightening of structural appearance is pointed out. The film makes use of animation, plans, scale models and actual scenes of buildings and exteriors, including some French cathedrals.

results.title: From 5 to 7.30
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Read and American Temperance Society
results.brief_description: Shows the effect that drinking parents can have on their children. Joe is deeply disturbed when one of his schoolmates, because of his drinking, is involved in a motor car accident. His conviction is strengthened because he see the results of social drinking and “the cocktail hour” in his own home, and in that of his girl-friend. He seeks advice from his coach at school, and attends a lecture by Dr Andrew C. Ivy, which results in his decision to “leave it alone”.

results.title: Friends and other people
results.creator_credit: Centre for Study of Higher Education
results.brief_description: A teaching model used to educate the intellectually disabled about types of relationships, clarifying social norms and behavioural expectations,in order to deal with loneliness, low self esteem and vulnerability to exploitation. Includes a booklet by Susie Smith and Judi Gray.

results.title: Friendly Fiji
results.brief_description: Fiji, one time home of warring tribes, is now a peace loving island with a thriving tourist trade. Palm beaches, ocean waters, traditional native ceremonies, and the cosmopolitan capital of Suva are among the many attractions. Outlines Fiji’s history from the first missionaries, to British Dependency in 1874, and the present government. Shows the ceremonial opening of the Legislative Council, soldiers in parade dres, and the official raising of the flag.
